On 23/01/2008, Kent Larsson <kent.larsson@...> wrote:
|>  One approach I've heard is to have the session beans as dumb forwarders
>  of requests to normal objects. And implement the actual business logic
>  in normal Java classes.

This is how I do it and it works very well.  It enforces a clear
separation between application logic, which is written as normal
object-oriented code, and the J2EE technology.  That keeps all the
awkward design issues of the J2EE framework well outside the
application.  The classes that refer to the J2EE framework are just an
adapter layer between the transaction management of the app container
and the objects of the application itself.

It means that you can easily test the application code in plain JUnit
(and jMock).

You'll need end-to-end tests to ensure that the adapter layer works as
expected.  But you have those already, I expect.

--Nat
